text:
Sara (00:00):
On this episode,

we showcase the journey of Perfect Corp, a leader 
in artificial intelligence and augmented reality

virtual try-on solutions for beauty and fashion. 
Hear about how they leverage AWS and generative

AI to enhance accuracy and personalization 
across their portfolio, driving innovation

and superior customer experiences at scale while 
reducing costs and ensuring security. [00:00:30]

Well, I'm excited to welcome Wayne Liu, 
president and chief growth officer and

co-founder of Perfect Corp. Wayne, 
thanks so much for being here today.

Wayne (00:42):
Thank you for having me,
I'm very exciting to share our experience.

Sara (00:46):
And from AWS,

we have Danny Wang, business development 
manager. Danny, great to have you here.

Danny (00:52):
Yeah, good to be here, thank you.

Sara (00:54):
And also from AWS, we

have Roger Wang, our solutions architect. Roger, 
thank [00:01:00] you, also, for being here today.

Roger (01:02):
Thank you, Sarah.

Sara (01:03):
So Wayne, for our

international audience, can you tell 
us a little bit about Perfect Corp?

Wayne (01:08):
Yeah, so Perfect Corp is a technology company.

Basically, we are using AI and AR, augmented 
reality, so as our base, but the interesting

here is, our application is mainly to the beauty 
and fashion industry, so we cover the technology

from virtual try-ons, so you can virtually try the 
makeup, all the way to [00:01:30] skin analysis.

Of course, we using AI, deep learning, to 
understand your skin, and then, to understand your

skin tone and the cases. And then, we do hair, we 
do a virtual try-on accessory. So we cover lots of

different aspects of the fashion and the beauty 
industry. Yeah, so 10 years in the business,

global, so we are in the many different country. 
We are working with a lot of big brand, globally.

Sara (01:59):
Fantastic, [00:02:00] and

I can imagine that in the beauty industry, 
that perfection is super important, isn't it,

to get the tones right, to get those 
recommendations right for your customers?

Wayne (02:12):
Yeah, yes, absolutely, so that's why our company's

name is perfect. So you have to be precise, when 
you talk about beauty, you have to be perfect.

Sara (02:22):
So can you tell us a little

bit about the technology estate that you had? 
What were you trying to do with AWS in this case?

Wayne (02:29):
Yeah, [00:02:30] so we collaborate

with AWS, and also, using AWS to service in many 
different way. Mainly, I would say in the three

very important part. The first one is really 
the platform architecture, the infrastructure.

Because as I said, we are a global company, 
we operate 24/7, because of global, somewhere,

sometime, is always somebody using our service, 
so that's why stability is very important. Also,

we are working with [00:03:00] more than 650 
brand globally, so that's why you can see the

high demand. And then, also, we are constantly 
growing, so scalability is super important,

so that's why working with AWS as a platform 
infrastructure, that's super important, and also,

as I said, because we are using AI technology. 
So AI is a constant involving, very fast,

and our customer, sometimes they just come with 
some idea, we developed some new AI application.

that's why we require very dynamic and the 
versatile infrastructure in the AI development,

specifically. So we rely heavily on the deep 
learning technology, and right now, generative AI,

the larger language models training, that one 
is super, super important. And then, the last

but not the least is, as I said, we work on 650 
brand globally across, can be like, 80 different

country. So you can imagine the complexity 
[00:04:00] of a compliance and the security,

so that's why we need to work with a company to 
comply their local data protection regulation and

all kinds of compliance. So that's [inaudible 
00:04:14] I saw like a GDPR. So that's why

working with AWS is really offering us a service 
to the global customers' safety and security side.

Sara (04:24):
Fantastic, and Danny,

those key themes around infrastructure, 
advanced [00:04:30] technologies,

and access to the latest technology, as well 
as that grounding and security, resonates,

I'm sure, with you, in terms of the work 
that you do with customers all the time.

Danny (04:40):
Yeah, absolutely,

so I think from day one, Perfect set the scale at 
the global scale for their application, so I think

for scaling is a really important thing for them. 
So at the beginning, about 2016, they have a huge

demand for a CPU, but at that time, we didn't 
introduce the auto-scaling [00:05:00] group for

them at the beginning, but when their business is 
suspending really huge from all around the world,

and we introduced the auto-scaling group for them 
to expand the usage of the CPU. And later on,

they have the huge demand for GPU, as well, 
because gen AI is expanding in their application,

as well. So we also add the GPU at the 
auto-scaling group for them to control the

usage and the performance, and also, the cost 
for them to have the better control for that.

Sara (05:30):
[00:05:30] Absolutely.

And Roger, maybe you can get into some of the 
architectural patterns for this latest use of

generative AI and deep learning in providing 
that kind of virtual try-on capabilities.

Roger (05:43):
Yeah, for sure, and one thing I would like

to also highlight is, Perfect not only has the app 
for the consumer side, they also have the control

plan and all the infrastructure and management 
tools for their clients on the business side,

as well. So imagine us having to [00:06:00] 
figure out, how can we enable their customers

on the business side of things. And so, they also 
do a lot of tracking [inaudible 00:06:08], and

you can imagine all the good stuff that a SaaS 
company, like the work with AWS, we offer them

a lot of multi-tenant and consultation about 
how they should decide their product, mirroring

what AWS has done in the past, specifically 
on the generative AI side. Because they are

the pioneers in the [00:06:30] AI and beauty AI 
space, they also leverage our GPU resources a lot.

(06:36):
So you can imagine, back

in the days, starting from 2015 to maybe 2023, 
it's more like a CPU-intensive kind of workload,

but as we enter into the generative era, they kind 
of starting having to balance between, how am I

going to do some of the [00:07:00] creative and 
generation on the server side a little bit more,

rather than having all the requests having to deal 
with on the client side. So you can imagine there

are some architectural balances that need to 
have a trade off. What if the picture that the

customer generate is not appropriate? They have to 
implement a layer on top of the existing platform,

and then, having more security and safeguards and 
guard duty kind of [00:07:30] security checks on

top of each other. So that's how we have been 
helping them, and then, involve the entire

technology side, and then, make change along 
the way as they expand into more countries.

Sara (07:43):
That flexibility,

you mentioned that, Wayne, and versatility and 
optionality that you have in terms of working,

so important for meeting the demand of 
your global customers, is that right?

Wayne (07:58):
Yes, yes, yes. And then, also,

so [00:08:00] talk about, I'll say, the scale. I 
want to add some number to make sure the customer,

the audience here, can have some idea about, 
when we talk about the sheer amount at the scale,

what's the scale? So basically, I keep on getting 
customer, however, the thing is that, even when I

see this number, I get a little bit shocked. Wow, 
it's a lot. So let me share with you, we are using

the Amazon's EMR, so EMR, [00:08:30] the elastic 
map reduce service. So we process 2.5 billion,

that's B, 2.5 billion consumer event, and 200 
million API inquiry per day, so you can see that

your service actually provide us a safeguard and 
the infrastructure to process so many requests per

day. And also, it's dynamic, because sometime, if 
we launch some new [00:09:00] product, the demand

can surge immediately, just surge it, or the 
customer launches ... We have some partner that

launches some new service. So that's why, to be 
versatile and dynamic and valuable, it's really,

really important, so based on this number, we 
are using PDN or [inaudible 00:09:16] as a unit.

Sara (09:18):
Amazing, and Danny,

that elasticity, so important in the value 
proposition of what we're providing. Can

you talk a little bit about some of 
the [00:09:30] capabilities there and

the approach for using serverless, 
etc., that we were able to bring?

Danny (09:36):
Right, so I want to tell a

story regarding the EMR that Wayne just mentioned. 
That is a good practice for working backward,

like in Amazon algorithm. So one thing is 
that, we are discussing with Perfect how

to optimize the user interface and the 
user experience at that time, and that,

we want to, working backward, how can we know 
what is [00:10:00] really happening on the app,

and what is really customer, that end user is 
doing with our apps, so that we are starting

to collect the end user click stream, so that we 
collected all these events and put it in the EMR?

(10:14):
So you can imagine that there's over 60 millions

of active user at that time for the apps, and that 
we can analyze all these event logs in the EMR,

so including which lipsticks, putting in the 
which location, which of the color is more popular

[00:10:30] being clicked, and what is the relation 
between the clicking so that we can also produce

the report for that, what is the really important 
location or what color, what is the brand that is

popular to the end user? So this is how we use 
the EMR so that we can analyze all the things.

Sara (10:48):
Fantastic, Wayne,

those insights that you're able to then garner 
for your customers around their end customers'

usage of the system is probably [00:11:00] 
a differentiator for you, is that right?

Wayne (11:02):
Yes, yes, absolutely, because when

Danny talk about this analytic data, that's one 
of our strengths, because we provide intelligence.

We're not just let the customer blindly try the 
makeup, because actually, we understand where,

how, and what color they are trying. So we analyze 
it, we provide this intelligence back to ... So

we have a B2B and B2C basis. For the B2B, we 
provide this intelligence back to the brand,

so brand [00:11:30] is treat this a very valuable 
insight, because they know what and where and how

this customer try their product, or even, they 
have a skin concern, so they know what kind of

skin concern their customers really focus on. And 
on the B2C side, of course, with a sheer amount

of data, we need to analyze the log, and sometime, 
maybe something happens, so we can quickly go back

to a log and check. So the EMR's the capability 
to provide us all this intelligent [00:12:00] data

and analytical ... The methodology, is 
very, very important, super critical to us.

Sara (12:07):
Absolutely. And Roger,

I want to go back to something that 
Wayne had mentioned in the beginning

around security and compliance, and 
some of that built-in capabilities

that we have. Do you want to speak to 
that a little bit about how we helped?

Roger (12:23):
Yeah, for sure,

so I think Perfect do a lot of things to protect 
their customers, and that reflect [00:12:30] on

the architectural choices they made. In fact, 
the products skewed from the beauty brands are

actually trained in-house, but all the renderings 
are happening on the client side. So they don't

collect all the sensitive data in terms of your 
skin, and then, all the different colors and

stuff like that, but also, because they need to 
be very, very precise. So you can imagine, as they

expand into different countries, and then, there 
are different regulatory compliance [00:13:00]

that they need to be compliant with, so how to 
balance between, what are the data that I need

to collect versus what are the data that I need to 
protect, and then, refine my services, etc., etc?

(13:15):
So they leverage a lot of

security services, on the front end side, they use 
the WAF to make sure that there's no different,

unnecessary attacks that are hitting their 
platform. [00:13:30] And also, they use a lot of

guard duty to making sure that all the traffics 
are, is there any patterns? And then, using

messages to figure out any columns that might be 
sensitive data they need to be doing maskings.

And then, also, how can they do those kind of 
on-device machine learning, and then, infer the

anonymous traffics without having to know what IP 
address this customer is coming from, etc., etc.?

(13:58):
And then, because of all [00:14:00] those

very rigid security compliance requirements, 
recently, we've been working with them to say,

hey, how can you do this on your regular basis? 
So we help them introduce some security incidents,

event management platform using open search, 
and then, help their backend and engineering

team to adopt those kinds of solutions, 
like right to use immediately, a launch

that they can use immediately, not 
having to put together all themselves.

Sara (14:29):
Right, [00:14:30] right. When we often talk

in this podcast about experimentation and failure, 
and that kind of speaks to some of that, like

being resilient and building in the capacity and 
capabilities for your system to evolve over time,

but was there anything particular that you would 
point out or think of that was an obstacle you

had to overcome during the development of these 
capabilities [00:15:00] for your end customers?

Wayne (15:02):
What Roger said, actually

is super important, because the data privacy. So 
thanks, Roger, actually explained this, we render

in the client side, so that one, we constantly 
get ask, because we are taking the face,

so that can be very sensitive, but every time we 
get into the contract and everything, the access,

to show them the architecture. So they say, how 
can you not get my data, my customer's data, but

still rendering, [00:15:30] and say, let me show 
it to you? So whenever we show this architecture

to them, we pass the security assessment. So 
that one's super important, because for us,

protect the data, especially we are dealing 
with the face. So that's super important.

(15:45):
And also,

second thing is availability. So as Danny 
just says, when we started, it's primary AR,

so we do lots of the CPU, [00:16:00] and then, 
later, we transfer into the GPU because it's AI,

so this transition, so the availability 
is super important. So we are very happy,

currently, we can achieve like a 99.99% of 
their service availability, because the customer

doesn't really matter, they don't care about 
if you are transitioning, doing architecture,

rendering, or whatever, they only need 
something is available when they need it.

(16:27):
So that's why,

the smooth transition, [00:16:30] it was an 
obstacle, because we have a concern, okay, what

happen if we transfer, we transfer something, and 
transition to something, and then, the service,

if they have a interruption or something, 
our customer won't be happy? But actually,

it doesn't happen. So that's why I guess it's 
a perfect collaboration with the AWS team,

so make all this transition very smooth. 
So that's why it's something fundamental,

security, privacy, and then, provide the customer 
peace of mind. That's something we really care

about, [00:17:00] and then, we are happy AWS team 
actually help us to get through the obstacle.

Sara (17:05):
Fantastic. I know this is an ongoing effort,

but maybe you can give us a sense of where we 
are in terms of the infusing these gen AI and

deep learning capabilities into the product, and 
where we are in terms of going to production.

Wayne (17:25):
Yeah, so great question,

because we are in the era of generative [00:17:30] 
AI, and then, we are also still learning,

because generative AI is a little bit different 
from, I always call it, classic AI, right? So you

train the model, when the model is stable, you 
put into your production. But generative AI is

generally something in the fly, so that's why 
we can see, especially if we get some popular

feature coming out, suddenly, we get lots of 
searches. So that's why how to ... And also,

because from our B2B customer, or even 
B2C customer, [00:18:00] sometimes we set

a cap on the business reason, so we cannot just 
[inaudible 00:18:04] and just do unlimited access.

(18:06):
So that's why moving to the

future is something we really need to focus on and 
solve, is, of course, the scalability. And also,

this scalability can be into a second. In couple 
of seconds, you may need to help us to increase

a hundred millions capacity, something like that. 
And also, why we hit the cap, [00:18:30] do we

have any tolerance or any margin to continue 
the service without the interruption? So I

guess that's something more like a new, because 
of development of a generative AI, and then,

create some new challenge for us. But again, 
that's a challenge that turned into opportunity.

So I'll say, besides everything, we'll just 
business as usual, but for generative AI,

this availability, and then, in the very short 
[00:19:00] period of time, how can we control

the server, the service assessment, and 
then, also, maintain the reliability?

Sara (19:09):
I love that notion

of turning the challenge into opportunity, 
and Danny, that's something we see with a

lot of our customers, isn't it, in the 
experimentation with generative AI,

but doing that in a safe and controlled 
manner so that they can make sure that

they maintain that high availability and 
quality for their customers, is that right?

Danny (19:30):
[00:19:30] Yeah, of course, and I

think Perfect Corp is a really good example for a 
Taiwanese company that always accept the challenge

and explore to a different market. So for example, 
at the beginning, they are having a B2B business

for cosmetic brand, and later on, they have 
switched to the B2C market for the apps which you

can download from the iOS or Android system. And 
from now on, they start to try the generative AI

solution, and also, they are stepping [00:20:00] 
into the medical industry right now. Yeah,

so for these GPU usage, then we need to see the 
problem in more detail and in more accuracy.

(20:12):
For example,

they have the new apps called the Skincare 
Pro, and they have the Reshape Simulator,

these kind of application is doing in the medical 
industry, so that, for example, like Skincare Pro,

we analyze more than 10 different kinds of skin 
problem so [00:20:30] that we need to see the

problem in detail and accuracy. For example, we 
cannot mix up the difference between the pimple

and a mole because that's a totally different 
things, although we need to analyze the skin

problem in more detail. And for example, 
the Reshape Simulator, we need to show,

what is the difference before and after the 
surgery from the doctor so that these kind

of application from gen AI is really good things 
that we can see that [00:21:00] is a application

produced by Perfect Corp, and we see that 
there is more opportunity coming in the future?

Sara (21:07):
So that's really

interesting, tell us a little bit 
more about these two products, Wayne.

Wayne (21:13):
Yeah, so Danny, actually, I have a good news for

you, while you are talking about the Skincare Pro, 
you said 10 concern. Actually, we already improved

getting to 14 different concern, you can see how 
fast it is. So basically, Skincare Pro is a very

easy to use tool. It's a software [00:21:30] 
tool, so the dermatologist or aesthetician, you

can download and put into your iPad. No complex 
installation, you use it just like app, and you

can start doing that. So just scan the faces, and 
then, we will tell you the 14 different concern,

the common concern from your customer or your 
client. So for example, the surveillance of their

wrinkle, their pore, or if they have redness, so 
we'll graphically show on your faces, and then,

we give [00:22:00] you a numerical number so you 
can see how your skin compared to other people.

(22:04):
So that's why it sounds

pretty simple, but actually, it's not, it takes 
us years of doing the deep learning, and now,

we offered it. And then, also another one, which 
we just launch, we call the Aesthetic Simulator,

basically, that one is for plastic surgeon. 
So most of customer, what happened to them,

the problem, the pain point is, when 
they go into a doctor, plastic surgeon,

they want to do something, [00:22:30] they want 
to do reshape. However, what happened is, they are

wondering about what will happen, what would look 
like, what will look like after the surgery. So

usually, at this moment, they show you some photos 
before and after, but it's other people's faces,

it's not your faces. So what we are doing here is, 
we are using your faces, of course goes through

a complicated learning, the AI learning, deep 
learning process, and also, generative AI, because

we need to create, we need to create based on 
what [00:23:00] we learn, what will happen to you.

(23:02):
So your doctor say,

okay, so you probably need to do a chin 
lifting, and then, by doing this surgery,

you'll get 70% improvement on your chin. 70%, 
what does that mean? But we graphically show

you what that 70% improvement means. You can 
say, oh, okay, so I understand. So actually,

that solve a very fundamental problem, who is that 
we empower the customer, because when customer

come to the doctor office, [00:23:30] they 
are always vulnerable because they are facing

something unknown. So that's why, with the new 
AI development, we get into the medical field,

which Danny just talking about. And also, going 
to medical field, we need more data security and

privacy protection, so that's why, again, go 
back to the AWS, provide us this environment.

Sara (23:52):
Yep, so much

exciting opportunity for expansive use 
of these technologies. Well, Wayne,

Danny, and Roger, [00:24:00] thank you so much 
for being here and sharing your story with us,

and I'll just ask us to end on maybe some 
reflections that you've had in the course of

this work that you've done that you would share 
with our customers. I'll start with you, Roger.

Roger (24:14):
Yeah, for sure,

I think we mentioned this a little bit during 
the course of this conversation, like having the

open mindset, and then, having the resiliency in 
terms of open to what the market is telling you,

and then, use [00:24:30] AWS technology to 
put together something really quick, and then,

get the feedback, and then, work with us. I think 
we really appreciate the relationship between

the Perfect Corp and our account team, they 
always tell us what they want to do, and then,

we get the feedback, we brainstorm what's the best 
solution for them, and then, they test the market,

and then, we go from there, and they iterate. 
And that's kind of like working backward,

and they very much adopt our leadership 
principles, as well. So I'm feeling like I'm

working with [00:25:00] my AWS coworkers from 
the other company, so I really appreciate that.

Sara (25:05):
Nice, Danny, how about you?

Danny (25:07):
Yeah, so I think

working with Perfect Corp, we are not only the 
relationship between a vendor and a customer,

we are also a real partnership between us. 
Because for example, we arrange Perfect Corp

to have a speech and at a booth in Taiwan for 
the retail forum so that we can connect more

different retail customer with a Perfect Corp, 
so [00:25:30] they can also expand their market

no matter in their original industry or the extra 
industry they want to explore in the future. So I

think that is ... Also, we are helping, and 
also, we are cooperating with Perfect Corp.

Sara (25:44):
Wonderful. Wayne,
I'll give you the final words, final reflections.

Wayne (25:49):
So we are in the technology world,

and then, people, the market, the customer, our 
shareholder, expect us to innovate it, so that's

why we always [00:26:00] run, and we run fast. 
But the thing here is, as Danny said, while we are

running, we need to have somebody to partner. You 
need to have people to set up the table to provide

you the water so you won't dehydrate, right? So 
you have a water there, so that's why I said,

running, running fast, and then, jumping, 
jumping higher, but you always need to find

a good partner to help you to put the safety 
nets or put the table to provide you the water.

(26:29):
So that's

why [00:26:30] you can have a peace of mind, you 
can run fast, you can jump high. So that's why,

in this reflection, I see getting AWS and Amazon 
in general as our partner is really help us. It's

not only a partnership, it's basically 
an ecosystem, so that we grow, we move,

and then, you help us to grow. So that's 
my reflection, we are very happy, and then,

we are looking forward to continue explore 
the uncharted territory of a generative AI

and turn all these [00:27:00] obstacles 
and challenge into the opportunity.

Sara (27:04):
Fantastic,

I love the metaphor of a long distance 
race and really looking at that stamina

that you have to continue to invent on behalf 
of your customers. So thank you so much, Wayne,

for being here today. Danny, Roger, again, 
wonderful to catch up with you. Thank you.

Wayne (27:21):
You're welcome, thank you.
